In scenarios where Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) cloud service providers do not permit on-premise audits by their customers, the auditor should consider alternative approaches to assess the security controls effectively. Among the options provided, the best approach is:

A. use other sources of available data for evaluating the customer’s controls.

This approach involves leveraging existing documentation, reports, and certifications, such as Service Organization Control (SOC) reports, ISO/IEC 27001 certifications, or other third-party audit reports that the cloud service provider may have. These documents can offer valuable insights into the provider's security posture and controls, allowing the auditor to evaluate whether the provider's environment meets the necessary security and compliance requirements. This method helps maintain an effective audit process without direct access to the provider’s premises.

Selected Answer: A
CCAK P#272 Contracts with cloud IaaS providers will often preclude first- or second-party audits. (CSPs consider on-premises audits a security risk, given that multiple on-premises audits by many customers would present logistical and security challenges.) Consequently, the assessor will need to evaluate other sources of data the customer used in its due diligence effort, such as third-party certification and attestations, self-assessments, white papers, technical documentation, etc.

The primary reason fieldwork audit papers are reviewed by an audit manager, even when the cloud auditor is highly experienced, is:

B. Professional standards

Professional auditing standards, such as those from organizations like the Institute of Internal Auditors (IIA) or the International Federation of Accountants (IFAC), require a review process to ensure the quality and consistency of audit work. These standards mandate that an independent review is conducted to verify that the audit has been performed in accordance with the relevant guidelines and to ensure that all findings are adequately supported and documented. This review process helps maintain the integrity and credibility of the audit results.

Selected Answer: B

One of the main reasons for this wide adoption is that the professional standards that underpin these CPA reports provide customers with a basis for relying on the report conclusions.

In this scenario, the best course of action would be:

B. Report the weakness as observed.

Although the database is out of scope for the current audit, it is still important to report any identified weaknesses. By documenting and reporting the issue, the auditor ensures that relevant stakeholders are informed, and appropriate actions can be taken to address the weakness. This approach maintains transparency and allows the organization to assess the risk and determine the necessary steps to mitigate it. It's essential to adhere to the defined scope of the audit, but reporting observed weaknesses outside of the scope can help improve overall security and risk management.

Selected Answer: B
CCAK P#89 The scope of a cloud platform security assessment depends on the CSPs and cloud services that support and deliver the technology target of the audit. A complex or multi-CSP environment will require careful scoping to manage the size of the review. In general, the assessor should start with targeting a broad scope that encompasses not just the services used to deliver a particular business system, but all relevant and supporting cloud services. After sizing the scale of the resulting audit work, elements may need to be deprioritized or removed (with rationales clearly documented).

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C. Validate if the strategy covers all activities required to continue and recover prioritized activities within identified time frames and agreed capacity, aligned to the risk appetite of the organization including the invocation of continuity plans and crisis management capabilities.

This choice is critical because it ensures that the strategy comprehensively addresses the ability to maintain and restore operations within acceptable time frames and capacity. It aligns with the organization's risk appetite and includes the activation of continuity plans and crisis management capabilities. This validation ensures that the organization can effectively respond to and recover from disruptions, maintaining operational resilience in line with strategic objectives.
